question: How will the Resource Allocation Competition (RAC) be affected by the infrastructure transition?
answer: The Resource Allocation Competition will be impacted by this transition, but the application process remains the same.

question: Will 2024/25 RAC allocations still be valid during the transition period?
answer: Yes, 2024/25 allocations will remain in effect on retiring clusters while each cluster remains in service.

question: When will the 2025/26 RAC allocations be fully implemented?
answer: The 2025/26 allocations will be implemented everywhere once all new clusters are in service.

question: What happens if a user holds both a 2024 and a 2025 RAC award during the transition?
answer: If you hold both a 2024 and a 2025 RAC award, you will experience a period when neither award is available to you because old clusters will be out of service before all new ones are available.

question: Can users compute on new clusters before their 2025 RAC allocations are active?
answer: Yes, users will be able to compute with their default allocation (def-xxxxxx) on each new cluster as soon as it goes into service.

question: When will 2025 RAC allocations become available on the new clusters?
answer: The 2025 RAC allocations will only become available when all new clusters are in service.

question: Where can users find more training opportunities?
answer: Users can discover more training opportunities through Explora, accessible at https://explora.alliancecan.ca.

question: What is the course title for the 3-part series offered by Simon Fraser University (SFU) / West DRI?
answer: The course title is "Introduction to HPC on Alliance Clusters (3-part series)".

question: Who instructs the "Introduction to HPC on Alliance Clusters" course?
answer: Alex Razoumov instructs the "Introduction to HPC on Alliance Clusters" course.

question: When is the "Introduction to HPC on Alliance Clusters" webinar series scheduled?
answer: The "Introduction to HPC on Alliance Clusters" webinar series is scheduled for Thursdays: September 25, October 2 & October 9, 2025, at 10:00 AM PT, with each session lasting 2 hours.

question: What topics are covered in the "Introduction to HPC on Alliance Clusters" course?
answer: The course covers hardware overview; tools & software environment; a brief tour of OpenMP, MPI, HPC Python (Dask, Ray), Chapel, Julia; compiling serial/shared/distributed codes; using Slurm (batch & interactive), benchmarking, submitting many jobs, estimating resources, and managing permissions, including demos and hands-on exercises.

question: Who is the target audience for the "Introduction to HPC on Alliance Clusters" training?
answer: The target audience for the "Introduction to HPC on Alliance Clusters" training is new or prospective HPC users on Canada's DRI systems.

question: How can I register for the "Introduction to HPC on Alliance Clusters" course?
answer: You can register for the "Introduction to HPC on Alliance Clusters" course at https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLScmO38yhWL4t48QmZ7ka26hTeUlzeHe4CF90d2cJRTBysKf3w/viewform.

question: What is "HPC105: Intro to SciNet and Trillium"?
answer: "HPC105: Intro to SciNet and Trillium" is a self-guided online course on using SciNet systems (Trillium), including account set-up, first login, running computations, and workflow migration guidance for returning users from legacy systems.

question: Who provides the "HPC105: Intro to SciNet and Trillium" course?
answer: SciNet provides the "HPC105: Intro to SciNet and Trillium" course.

question: When was the "HPC105: Intro to SciNet and Trillium" course updated and when is it available?
answer: The "HPC105: Intro to SciNet and Trillium" course was updated in August 2025 and is available anytime.

question: Who is the audience for "HPC105: Intro to SciNet and Trillium"?
answer: The audience for "HPC105: Intro to SciNet and Trillium" includes prospective users of Trillium and new users to SciNet.

question: What is the estimated time to complete the "HPC105: Intro to SciNet and Trillium" course?
answer: The estimated time to complete the "HPC105: Intro to SciNet and Trillium" self-guided online course is approximately 4 hours.

question: How can one access the "HPC105: Intro to SciNet and Trillium" course?
answer: The course can be accessed at https://education.scinet.utoronto.ca/enrol/index.php?id=1389, and an Alliance CCDB account is required.

question: What is the focus of the "Migrating to the upgraded national systems" webinar?
answer: The webinar addresses concerns and questions users of existing systems might have about the major upgrade, including workflow impact, changes to job scheduling and file systems, using increased computing capacity, and GPU computing changes.

question: Who was the instructor for the "Migrating to the upgraded national systems" webinar?
answer: Sergey Mashchenko from SHARCNET was the instructor for the "Migrating to the upgraded national systems" webinar.

question: When was the "Migrating to the upgraded national systems" webinar held?
answer: The "Migrating to the upgraded national systems" webinar was held on Wednesday, July 30, 2025, at 12:00 PM EDT.

question: Which old clusters were renamed to what new names as part of the upgrade?
answer: Graham became Nibi, Beluga became Rorqual, Cedar became Fir, and Niagara became Trillium. Narval was not upgraded this cycle.

question: Where can recordings of the "Migrating to the upgraded national systems" webinar be found?
answer: Recordings and materials from previous SHARCNET webinars are available at http://youtube.sharcnet.ca.

question: What tools are highlighted in the "Workflow Hacks for Large Datasets in HPC" webinar?
answer: The webinar highlights in-situ visualization, lossy 3D data compression, distributed storage, and DAR (Disk ARchiver) as valuable tools for research workflows involving large datasets.

question: Who presented the "Workflow Hacks for Large Datasets in HPC" webinar?
answer: Alex Razoumov from Simon Fraser University (SFU) / West DRI presented the "Workflow Hacks for Large Datasets in HPC" webinar.

question: When was the "Workflow Hacks for Large Datasets in HPC" webinar conducted?
answer: The "Workflow Hacks for Large Datasets in HPC" webinar was conducted on Tuesday, May 20, 2025, at 10:00 AM PT.

question: What is the target audience for the "Workflow Hacks for Large Datasets in HPC" webinar?
answer: The target audience for the "Workflow Hacks for Large Datasets in HPC" webinar is users working with large datasets.

question: Are there recordings available for the "Workflow Hacks for Large Datasets in HPC" webinar?
answer: Recordings and materials from previous related webinars are freely available at https://training.westdri.ca.
